prior_works.title: Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Models
prior_works.authors: Jonathan Ho, Ajay Jain, Pieter Abbeel
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced the diffusion generative modeling framework that underpins non-autoregressive trajectory generation in diffusion planners, the sampling stochasticity of which TAT explicitly mitigates.

prior_works.title: Diffuser: Diffusion Models for Planning
prior_works.authors: Michael Janner, Yilun Du, Joshua B. Tenenbaum, Sergey Levine
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established planning via trajectory diffusion as a non-autoregressive alternative to autoregressive sequence models; TAT is designed as a training-free wrapper to stabilize such diffusion planners by aggregating sampled trajectories into a robust tree.

prior_works.title: Classifier-Free Diffusion Guidance
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Represents a widely used sampling-time guidance method to steer diffusion outputs; TAT offers an orthogonal, training- and sampler-agnostic alternative by post-hoc aggregating multiple predicted trajectories rather than modifying the diffusion dynamics.

prior_works.title: Deep Reinforcement Learning in a Handful of Trials Using Probabilistic Dynamics Models (PETS)
prior_works.authors: Kurtland Chua, Roberto Calandra, Rowan McAllister, Sergey Levine
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Popularized trajectory sampling and elite selection (via CEM) for robust MPC; TAT similarly leverages multiple sampled rollouts but aggregates them in a dynamic tree to marginalize unreliable states instead of selecting a single elite trajectory.

prior_works.title: Bandit Based Monte-Carlo Planning (UCT)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrated how rollouts can be organized into a state-action search tree with principled node prioritization; TAT echoes this idea by building a trajectory aggregation tree that prioritizes impactful nodes and prunes unreliable branches.

prior_works.title: Randomized Kinodynamic Planning (RRT)
prior_works.authors: Steven M. LaValle, James J. Kuffner Jr.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced tree-structured exploration over state spaces using sampled trajectories; TAT’s dynamic tree over states/trajectories draws on this intuition, but uses it to fuse multiple diffusion-generated plans and downweight infeasible regions.

prior_works.title: MBPO: Model-Based Policy Optimization
prior_works.authors: Michael Janner, Justin Fu, Marvin Zhang, Sergey Levine
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Showed that aggregating information from multiple model rollouts/ensembles can curb compounding errors; TAT similarly reduces stochastic risk by aggregating historical and current diffusion trajectories to form more reliable decisions.

synthesis_narrative:
Trajectory Aggregation Tree (TAT) is motivated by the success and limitations of diffusion-based planners. Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Models established the non-autoregressive generative machinery that enables trajectory-level sampling, and Diffuser extended this idea to decision-making, showing strong long-horizon performance but also exposing the practical risk of infeasible samples due to stochasticity. Prior attempts to steer diffusion outputs—such as classifier-free guidance—modify the sampling dynamics or require auxiliary conditioning; in contrast, TAT aims to be training- and sampler-agnostic.
To achieve robustness without retraining, TAT synthesizes ideas from sample-based planning and tree search. PETS popularized sampling many trajectories and selecting elites (often via CEM), illustrating how aggregate statistics over trajectories can improve reliability; TAT generalizes this by organizing repeated diffusion rollouts into a dynamic state/trajectory tree, rather than committing to a single elite path. Classical tree-search principles further inspire TAT’s structure: UCT shows how simulated rollouts can populate a search tree with principled node prioritization, while RRT demonstrates how sampling can grow trees that explore feasible regions of state space. Finally, MBPO’s use of ensembles and multiple rollouts to temper model bias aligns with TAT’s core mechanism—marginalizing unreliable states/branches by pooling evidence across historical and current predictions. Together, these strands directly inform TAT’s key contribution: a training-free, trajectory-aggregation tree that prioritizes robust nodes and resists stochastic failure modes of diffusion planners.
